context: <b5_0>Political economy<b5_0/> in anthropology is the application of the theories and methods of Historical Materialism to the <a0_0>traditional concerns<a0_0/> of anthropology, including, but not limited to, non-capitalist societies. Political Economy introduced questions of <a1_0>history and colonialism<a1_0/> to ahistorical anthropological <b6_0>theories of social structure and culture<b6_0/>. Three main areas of interest rapidly developed. The first of these areas was concerned with the "pre-capitalist" societies that were subject to evolutionary "tribal" stereotypes. Sahlins work on <a2_0>Hunter-gatherers<a2_0/> as the 'original affluent society' did much to dissipate that image. The second area was concerned with the vast majority of the world's <a3_0>population<a3_0/> at the time, <b7_0>the peasantry<b7_0/>, many of whom were involved in complex revolutionary wars such as in Vietnam. The third area was on colonialism, imperialism, and the creation of the capitalist world-system. More recently, these <b8_0>Political Economists<b8_0/> have more directly addressed issues of <a4_0>industrial (and post-industrial) capitalism<a4_0/> around the world.
